Policy text:
**Sunrise Technologies Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.0: Compensation and Benefits**
**Policy 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

3.  2.  1 General Overtime Policy: Sunrise Technologies recognizes its obligation to comply with all applicable federal and state laws regarding overtime compensation. As such, non-exempt employees will be compensated for overtime hours worked pursuant to the standards set forth herein and in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and applicable state law.

4.  2.  2 Overtime Compensation Calculation: For non-exempt employees located outside of California, overtime shall be calculated at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) in a workweek. However, for non-exempt employees located in California, overtime compensation shall be calculated in accordance with California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein. Specifically, for California employees, overtime compensation will be paid at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) in a workday or forty (40) in a workweek. Employees who work more than twelve (12) hours in a workday or more than eight (8) hours on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of a workweek shall be compensated at two (2) times their regular rate of pay. All overtime must be pre-approved by the employee’s supervisor, except in the instance of unforeseeable emergency. For the avoidance of doubt, this policy does not permit or authorize compensatory time off for overtime worked by non-exempt employees in California. Any violation of this Section may subject the employee to disciplinary action, up to and including termination. It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all hours worked.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Layoff Notification (WARN Act)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-15
**Effective Date:** 2024-02-01

This policy outlines Acme Corp's procedures for complying with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both federal and California-specific. Acme Corp is committed to providing employees with as much advance notice as possible in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation. This policy applies only to Acme Corp employees working in the state of California.

**California WARN Act:** California has its own version of the WARN Act, and it has stricter requirements than the federal version. California WARN act (CA WARN) rules apply if Acme Corp has 75 or more employees (either full-time or part-time) in California. If Acme Corp triggers a mass layoff which means laying off 50 or more employees at a single site of employment within any 30-day period, employees must receive written notice at least 60 days before the layoff date.

**Federal WARN Act:** Even if the California WARN Act does not apply (e.g., Acme Corp has between 75 and 99 employees in California, and does not trigger a mass layoff as defined above), the federal WARN Act might. The federal WARN act applies if Acme Corp has 100 or more employees (either full-time or part-time) nationwide, and we are planning a mass layoff of 50 or more employees at a single site of employment during a 30 day period.

Therefore, if Acme Corp has at least 75 employees in California, and is conducting a mass layoff of 50 or more employees at a single site, then we are required to notify affected employees at least 60 days prior to the layoff. This requirement is separate from, and in addition to, any severance or other benefits outlined in Policy 3.15, "Termination Benefits." If Acme Corp has at least 100 employees company-wide, and conducts a mass layoff of 50 or more employees at a single site in California, then we are also required to notify employees at least 60 days in advance.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.4.1. **Overtime Eligibility and Calculation:** This section applies solely to non-exempt employees physically working within the State of California. Pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515, Acme Corp. shall compensate eligible employees for overtime hours worked. Overtime shall be defined as all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any one workday or forty (40) hours in any one workweek. Notwithstanding the foregoing, hours worked beyond twelve (12) hours in any workday or for any hours worked on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of a workweek shall be compensated at twice the employee's regular rate of pay.

3.4.2. **Exemptions:** Certain employees, based on classification, may be exempt from overtime provisions as defined under applicable California and federal law. The determination of exempt status shall be made in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and California Labor Code Section 515 et seq., and will be detailed separately in the employee's offer letter or subsequent written notification.

3.4.3. **Meal Periods and Overtime:** For purposes of calculating overtime, unpaid meal periods are excluded from hours worked. An employee who fails to take a duly scheduled and permitted meal period, and consequently works in excess of eight (8) hours in a workday due to the omission of the meal period, remains eligible for overtime compensation for those hours exceeding eight, provided the missed meal period was not due to the employee's voluntary decision without the express or implied consent of their supervisor. For clarity and to ensure compliance, all employees working shifts greater than five hours will have a 30-minute meal break scheduled. The company reserves the right to modify the schedule of the meal break, but the employee is still entitled to the meal break and must not be penalized for taking the required break.

3.4.4 **Reporting Overtime:** All overtime hours must be pre-approved by the employee's supervisor prior to being worked, except in circumstances involving unforeseen emergencies. Any employee who believes they are entitled to overtime pay must submit a request to their supervisor no later than close of business on the Monday following the workweek in which the overtime hours were worked, which will be verified by the Supervisor prior to payment. Any employee that is not classified as an Active employee per Section 2.1 of this policy will not be eligible for overtime, regardless of classification or hours worked.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.14: Final Paycheck Procedures**
*Revision 2.0, Effective Date: 2024-01-01*

At Acme Corp, we aim to provide all employees with a clear understanding of our final paycheck procedures. This policy applies to all employees across the United States, in accordance with federal law. Should there be any questions regarding this policy, please consult the Employee Handbook section 1.2 or contact your HR representative.

Regarding the timing of final paychecks, our standard procedure is as follows. If an employee's employment with Acme Corp terminates, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, the final paycheck, which includes all accrued and unpaid wages, will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday, provided that all company property, including but not limited to laptops, mobile devices, and identification badges, has been returned to the company and properly checked in according to the procedures described in Section 2.5. This ensures accurate calculation and processing.

Notwithstanding the above, and to ensure compliance with applicable federal standards, if an employee has worked fewer than 60 hours in the 12 months preceding termination, and if the employee's tenure at Acme Corp was less than 3 months, then the final paycheck may be issued within fourteen (14) days of the termination date. Any exceptions to this policy must be approved in writing by the VP of HR (see Section 5.1 for contact information). This policy is designed to ensure all employees are compensated accurately and in a timely manner following the end of their employment. While Acme Corp strives for prompt payment, administrative considerations and payroll processing timelines necessitate adherence to the aforementioned procedures.

Policy text:
**Section 3.7: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Policy 3.7.A.1 - Revision 2024-10-26**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

(a) **General Provision:** This policy outlines the procedures regarding workforce reductions, including mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, to ensure compliance with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act ("WARN Act"), both federal and state (California) versions. This policy applies to all employees of GlobalTech Innovations, Inc. ("the Company"). The Company is committed to providing as much advance notice as reasonably practicable to affected employees in the event of a workforce reduction.

(b) **WARN Act Notice Requirements:** Pursuant to the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.), and the California WARN Act (California Labor Code §§ 1400-1408), the Company shall provide sixty (60) calendar days advance written notice to affected employees prior to any plant closing or mass layoff as defined under said statutes. However, notwithstanding the foregoing, if the employer.employee_count is less than 100, yet equal to or greater than 75, and the employee.location_state is California, and if a mass layoff, plant closing or relocation affects 50 or more employees, then the Company will provide the aforementioned sixty (60) day notice. The determination of who constitutes an "affected employee" shall be made in accordance with applicable law and regulations, including but not limited to the interpretation provided by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). This policy shall be interpreted in a manner consistent with providing the greatest level of protection to employees as afforded by applicable law. Notice shall be provided to the affected employees, the State Workforce Agency (SWA), and the chief elected official of the local government.

(c) **Exceptions:** Exceptions to the sixty (60) day notice requirement may apply under certain limited circumstances, as defined by the WARN Act, including the "unforeseeable business circumstances" exception, the "faltering company" exception, and the "natural disaster" exception. In such instances, the Company will provide as much notice as is practicable.

(d) **Coordination with Human Resources:** All workforce reductions must be coordinated with the Human Resources Department to ensure compliance with all applicable laws and company policies. Human Resources will maintain records of all notices provided under this policy.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

**Purpose:** To establish guidelines for overtime compensation in compliance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). This policy applies to all non-exempt employees of Acme Corp throughout the United States. Refer to Policy 3.1 for employee classification definitions.

**3.4.1 Overtime Eligibility and Rate:**

Acme Corp adheres to federal overtime regulations as stipulated in the FLSA. Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay for all hours worked exceeding 40 in a workweek. Overtime compensation will be paid at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay. This policy is designed to ensure consistent application of overtime regulations across all Acme Corp locations within the United States and to comply with federal law.

**3.4.2 Overtime Authorization:**

All overtime work must be authorized in advance by the employee’s supervisor. Employees who work overtime without prior authorization may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination. While Acme Corp recognizes that unforeseen circumstances may occasionally necessitate unscheduled overtime, employees are expected to communicate with their supervisors as soon as possible if overtime work is required. Failure to obtain prior authorization does not negate the employee’s entitlement to overtime pay for hours worked exceeding 40 in a workweek, but it may result in disciplinary action.

**3.4.3 Calculation of Overtime:**

Overtime hours are calculated based on the total number of hours worked in a workweek, which is defined as a fixed and regularly recurring period of 7 consecutive days. The workweek begins at 12:00 AM on Sunday and ends at 11:59 PM on Saturday. Paid time off, such as vacation or sick leave, is not considered hours worked for the purpose of calculating overtime. If a non-exempt employee's hours_worked_weekly exceeds 40, the employee will receive 1.5 times their regular hourly rate for each hour over 40.

**3.4.4 Recordkeeping:**

Accurate recordkeeping of hours worked is essential for compliance with the FLSA. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their start and end times, as well as any break periods, in the company’s timekeeping system. Supervisors are responsible for reviewing and approving employee time records on a weekly basis. Discrepancies in time records must be resolved promptly.

**3.4.5 Policy Exceptions:**

No exceptions to this policy are permitted without the express written approval of the Vice President of Human Resources.

Policy text:
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
*Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 1.2*

3.12.1. It is the policy of GlobalTech Solutions, Inc. to comply with all applicable state and federal laws regarding workforce reductions, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq., and the California WARN Act, Cal. Labor Code §§ 1400-1408.

3.12.2. In the event of a plant closing, mass layoff, or relocation as defined by the WARN Acts, the Company shall provide advance written notice to affected employees, designated employee representatives (if any), the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the chief elected official of the local government. "Affected employees" include employees who may reasonably be expected to experience an employment loss as a result of the proposed action. Notwithstanding Section 3.12.3, for employees whose primary work location is in California, GlobalTech Solutions, Inc. shall provide such notice at least sixty (60) calendar days prior to the date of the plant closing, mass layoff, or relocation if either (a) the employer has seventy-five (75) or more employees or (b) fifty (50) or more employees are affected by said mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation. For work locations outside of California, if the employer has less than one hundred (100) employees but more than seventy four (74) employees and a mass layoff impacts fewer than fifty employees, then no WARN notice is required.

3.12.3. For work locations outside of California, GlobalTech Solutions, Inc. shall provide such notice at least sixty (60) calendar days prior to the date of the plant closing, mass layoff, or relocation if the employer has one hundred (100) or more employees and the plant closing or mass layoff affects fifty (50) or more employees at a single site of employment, or a relocation occurs that results in an employment loss for fifty (50) or more employees at a single site of employment within any thirty (30) day period. Further clarification regarding the definition of an “employment loss” can be found in Section 1.5, Definitions.

3.12.4. The determination of whether a WARN event has occurred shall be made in good faith and based upon the best information available to the Company at the time.

Policy text:
**Pacific Dynamics HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01, Revision 1.0**

This policy outlines Pacific Dynamics' approach to Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) for our California employees. We aim to provide a supportive and compliant environment for employees needing time off for qualifying family or medical reasons.

**3.2.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

Eligible California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) may be able to receive up to 8 weeks of partial wage replacement (approximately 60-70% of your normal pay, as determined by the state) through California's PFL program. This benefit is for bonding with a new child (within one year of birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or caring for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling). To be eligible for PFL, your employee.sdi_contributor status must be set to 'true' and your employee.location_state must be equal to 'CA'. The leave.type must be either 'bonding' or 'caregiver'. We encourage you to apply for PFL through the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD).

**3.2.2 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

In addition to California PFL, employees who have worked for Pacific Dynamics for at least 12 months (employee.tenure_months >= 12) and have worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months prior to the leave start date (employee.hours_worked_12_months >= 1250), and whose employee.employment_status is 'active', are eligible for up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the FMLA. This only applies if Pacific Dynamics employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite (employer.employee_count_within_75_miles >= 50). FMLA leave can be used for the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent), or for your own serious health condition that makes you unable to perform the essential functions of your job. Note: If you are eligible for both PFL and FMLA, the leaves may run concurrently, however, FMLA is unpaid while PFL provides partial wage replacement.

Employees whose employee.location_state is not 'CA' will need to refer to Policy Section 3.3 for state-specific leave policies.

**GoldenGate Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.7: Compensation and Payroll**
**Policy 3.7.4: Final Paycheck Distribution**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

GoldenGate Solutions, Inc. is committed to ensuring timely and accurate compensation for all employees. This policy outlines the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees whose employment with GoldenGate Solutions has ended.

Generally, in accordance with federal law and except as otherwise provided for under applicable state law, a final paycheck, encompassing all earned but unpaid wages including accrued and unused vacation time as described in Policy 3.7.3, will be made available to the employee on the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination, resignation, or layoff. However, in situations where an employee is terminated involuntarily, and the employee's location_state is not in the list of states which mandate immediate payment (including but not limited to California, as defined under that state's Labor Code Sections 201 and 202), and provided the employee's employment_status is not "active", the final paycheck will be processed, and available for receipt, no later than the next regular payday following the last day of employment. For clarity, the parameters for determining "regular payday" are outlined in Policy 3.7.1 and are typically bi-weekly on Fridays. Exceptions to this policy may be granted at the discretion of the Chief Human Resources Officer, taking into consideration extenuating circumstances and the operational needs of GoldenGate Solutions. Any questions regarding the timing or distribution of final paychecks should be directed to the HR Department for clarification.

Policy text:
**Golden Gate Technologies – Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

Golden Gate Technologies is committed to complying with all applicable California labor laws. This policy applies to all non-exempt employees who work in California.

**Meal Breaks:** Employees working more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal period. This meal period should generally be taken before the end of the employee's fifth hour of work. However, if the total hours worked in a workday are no more than six (6) hours, the meal period may be waived by mutual consent of the employee and their supervisor. In situations where an employee is required to work more than ten (10) hours in a workday, a second thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal period is required unless the total hours worked are no more than twelve (12) hours AND the first meal period was not waived. Failure to comply with this policy, where the employee's actions contribute to the missed break (e.g., rejecting a properly offered break, and reporting such refusal to GGT), may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. Good faith efforts should be made to provide these breaks.

**Rest Breaks:** For every four (4) hours worked (or major fraction thereof), non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid ten (10)-minute rest period. To be clear, this means employees working between 3.5 and 4 hours will receive a rest break. Rest breaks should, where feasible, be taken in the middle of the four-hour work period. However, the timing of the rest break may be adjusted to accommodate operational needs. If an employee demonstrates a consistent pattern of being unable or unwilling to take breaks, despite GGT’s good faith efforts to provide such breaks, and these actions disrupt normal business operations, the employee may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination.

This policy is subject to change with or without notice. It is the employee’s responsibility to stay informed of company policy. Any questions regarding this policy should be directed to the Human Resources Department.

**Unified Global Enterprises, Inc. - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

3.12.1. **Policy Statement:** It is the policy of Unified Global Enterprises, Inc. ("the Company") to ensure the timely and accurate disbursement of final wages to all employees upon separation from employment, pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and other applicable federal regulations. This section outlines the procedures for determining the timing of the final paycheck.

3.12.2. **Final Paycheck Timing:** Notwithstanding any conflicting interpretations or applications of state law, including but not limited to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, the Company shall adhere to federal regulations regarding the issuance of final paychecks. Therefore, except as otherwise provided in Subsection 3.12.3, an employee's final paycheck, inclusive of all earned but unpaid wages, including accrued vacation time and other benefits legally required to be paid out upon termination, will be available on the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's separation date. If, however, the employee has been employed for less than twelve (12) months and their employment status changes to terminated due to involuntary separation or resignation, and the employee has worked less than 20 hours per week on average over their total tenure with the company, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of the separation. Definitions regarding "earned but unpaid wages" and "accrued vacation time" are outlined in Section 2.01 and Section 4.10 respectively. The Human Resources Department is responsible for ensuring compliance with this policy. This policy applies to all active and terminated employees, regardless of location, unless a specific agreement exists in writing that dictates otherwise.
